answers.author: Tim Bonnemann
answers.text:
Hi Gayle, 
Below are a number of tools that support paragraph-specific or sentence-specific commenting: 
1) Making Speeches Talk 
http://makingspeechestalk.com/crossover/ 
(the URL is for a pilot project, happy to connect you with the team) 
2) Stet 
"designed to collect, organize and grok comments on texts made available online for public comment." 
http://gitorious.org/stet 
(this might be very close to what you had developed earlier) 
3) Read+Comment 
http://readandcomment.com 
4) digress.it 
http://digress.it 
(Wordpress plugin) 
There are probably more. 
Would love to find out what solution you end up going with. Would also like to learn more about the software environment you used previously so we can add it to ParticipateDB (http://participatedb.com). All of the four tools mentioned above are already catalogued there. 
Thanks and good luck!

answers.text:
Hello Gayle,
I haven't been able to find anything quite like the system Charlotte County had in place; sounds very cool!  I have found other systems that might help your jurisdiction anyways:
Philadelphia, PA has used web-based CRM and 311 systems to get citizen input during a budget crisis:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/2935/Philly311_Engaging_Citizens_Serving_Customers
The League of Kansas Municipalities report that one jurisdiction creatively used a Facebook wall to better connect with citizens:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/3111/Web_20_The_Next_Step_in_Citizen_Engagement
I hope these help,
Gabe Brehm
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

Hi Gayle, 
We at Granicus have enjoyed a great partnership with Charlotte County for the past 8 years.  The County currently utilizes our Transparency Platform to integrate BOCC meeting information in 1 integrated public record:  http://charlotte.granicus.com/ViewPublisher.php?view_id=15
In accordance with your request above, we also have an online citizen collaboration platform that integrates with your current solution.  This allows you to:
•   Allow Citizens to Submit Comments on Legislative/Agenda Items
•   Present County Projects and get feedback via online Forums, Surveys, and Discussions
•   Allow Citizens to crowdsource, prioritize, and vote up the best ideas
•   Leverage these tools and integrate them to your Social Media Sites
•   Ability to run Reports and Analytics for your elected officials and staff

We would be happy to discuss with you at your convenience.   You can contact me @ 404-964-5389 or chris@granicus.com
Best Regards,

author: Gayle Moore
text:
In 2010, when Charlotte County was preparing a new comprehensive plan, we worked with the University of Central Florida (UCF) on an online platform for posting our draft documents for public review; part of the software developed for this purpose by the UCF computer lab ("PICT") involved the ability for citizens to comment on specific sections of the draft documents, for those comments to be moderated, and subsequently displayed next to the draft section they pertained to.  Staff could then respond in the same format to the comment, and other public comment could accrue on the same subject.  The PICT software was recognized nationally an a unique contribution to the citizen-comment process.
A document currently online in this software environment can be found here:
http://www2.charlottefl.com/CharterReview/main/about.aspx?message_id=Documents 
For various technical reasons, the software is not now useful (this may have to do with Microsoft Windows updates over the intervening years) and we are looking for any similar software solution to once again put pending legislation (our zoning code) before the public for comment.
We are soliciting suggestions for software options from the group, and all replies will be welcome.
title: Citizen feedback on proposed legislation
